person_1008.name: Johann AndreasWagner
person_1008.description: a German palaeontologist, zoologist and archaeologist who wrote several important works on palaeontology.

person_235.name: Marcus ElieserBloch
person_235.description: German physician and naturalist who specialised in the study of fish on which he published a 12 volume work with which Davy was familiar. (presumably in the French translation).

person_172.name: AntonioCanova
person_172.description: Italian sculptor and friend of the Davys.

person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_118.name: George GordonByron
person_118.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

person_098.name: JosephineDetela
person_098.description: The daughter of the landlord of the Laybach (Ljubljana) inn at which Davy stayed in 1827 and 1828. Davy nicknamed her 'Pepina'. In Consolations in Travel (1830) he portrayed her in idealised terms as his nurturing nurse.

person_956.name: Cain
person_956.description: A biblical figure in the Book of Genesis. He is the firstborn son of Adam and Eve and brother of Abel.

person_957.name: Julian
person_957.description: Julian was the Caesar of the West from 355 to 360 and Roman emperor from 361 to 363, as well as a notable philosopher and author in Greek. His rejection of Christianity, and his promotion of Neoplatonic Hellenism in its place, caused him to be remembered as Julian the Apostate in Christian tradition.

person_119.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
person_119.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

person_955.name: Constantine
person_955.description: Roman emperor from AD 306 to 337; he patronised Christianity and was converted to it on his deathbed.

person_031.name: JohnMilton
person_031.description: Milton was a poet and polemicist. He wrote the epic poem Paradise Lost.

person_795.name: Jupiter
person_795.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_1009.name: ElizabethFry
person_1009.description: an English prison reformer, social reformer, philanthropist and Quaker.

place_272.name: Mondsee
place_272.description: Mondsee is a town in Upper Austria located on the shore of the lake, Mondsee.

place_269.name: Kammersee
place_269.description: The Kammersee, or Attersee, is a lake in Upper Austria.

place_1350.name: Unterach am Attersee
place_1350.description: Unterach is a village in the Austria state of Upper Austria on the southern shore of lake Attersee in the centre of the Salzkammergut region.

place_268.name: Ager River
place_268.description: The Ager River in Austria is a tributary of the Traun.

place_197.name: Salzburg
place_197.description: Salzburg is an Austrian city on the border of Germany, with views of the Eastern Alps.

place_1339.name: Vöcklamarkt
place_1339.description: Town on the Vöckla river, between Vöcklabruck and Frankenmarkt

place_898.name: Vienna
place_898.description: Austria’s capital, lies in the country’s east on the Danube River.

place_586.name: Gorizia
place_586.description: Gorizia is a town and comune in north-eastern Italy, in the autonomous region of Friuli Venezia Giulia.

place_229.name: Bad Aussee
place_229.description: In Styria (Bad Aussee). Bad Aussee is a town in the Austrian state of Styria located at the confluence of the three sources of the Traun River.

place_1351.name: Traunstein
place_1351.description: Traunstein is a town in the south-eastern part of Bavaria, Germany, and is the administrative center of a much larger district of the same name.

place_258.name: Traun
place_258.description: The Traun is a river in Upper Bavaria, Germany. The nearly 29 kilometer long river is formed by the confluence of the Weiße Traun and the Rote Traun near Siegsdorf. It passes through Traunstein and Traunreut, and flows into the Alz near Altenmarkt an der Alz.

place_182.name: Traun
place_182.description: Traunfall in Desselbrunn, Upper Austria. Memoirs contains a poem Davy wrote about them, also in notebook 14E.

place_1264.name: Munich
place_1264.description: the capital of Bavaria in Germany

place_1352.name: Bad Aibling
place_1352.description: Bad Aibling is a spa town and former district seat in Bavaria on the river Mangfall, located some 56 km southeast of Munich.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_1235.name: Starnberg
place_1235.description: a town in Bavaria, Germany, some 30 kilometres southwest of Munich

place_1236.name: Kochelsee
place_1236.description: a picturesque glacial lake covering 2.3 square miles, fringed with mountains & wetlands.

place_1238.name: Füssen
place_1238.description: a town in Bavaria, Germany, just north of the Austrian border.

place_1239.name: Lech
place_1239.description: The river that runs through Füssen, and flows into the Forggensee.

place_1240.name: Kempten
place_1240.description: a town in Allgäu, about 28 miles from Füssen

place_1241.name: Röthenbach an der Pegnitz
place_1241.description: a town that would be on the route from Kempten to Bregenz

place_1242.name: Bregenz
place_1242.description: Today, a town in Austria on the shores of the Obersee.

place_328.name: Tyrol
place_328.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

place_1243.name: Appenzell
place_1243.description: a canton in the northeast of Switzerland, the southern part of which is mountainous

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_179.name: Albulae Aquae
place_179.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

place_1310.name: Lake Luichart
place_1310.description: a loch and reservoir in the Ross and Cromarty district of Highland Council Area

place_1306.name: Lusignano
place_1306.description: A hamlet in the municipality of Albenga, in the province of Savona, Italy.

place_1305.name: Wandle
place_1305.description: A tributary of the River Thames in south London, England. Davy writes a poem 'To the Wandle, or Vandalis' (notebook 14E, pp. 122-1) and writes about the river in Samonia.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_419.name: Mount's Bay
place_419.description: A bay on the English Channel coast of Cornwall, England, stretching from the Lizard Point to Gwennap Head.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_277.name: Innsbruck
place_277.description: Innsbruck is the capital of the Tyrol region of Austria, built on the banks of the Inn River.

place_972.name: Traunsee
place_972.description: A lake in the Salzkammergut, Upper Austria, Austria.

place_245.name: Ravenna
place_245.description: Ravenna is a city in the north-east of Italy, near the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_1353.name: Tahiti
place_1353.description: Tahiti is the largest island in French Polynesia, the South Pacific archipelago. Shaped like a figure-8, it's divided into Tahiti Nui (the larger, western section) and Tahiti Iti (the eastern peninsula). It was known as Otaheite in the time Davy was writing.

place_071.name: London
place_071.description: The capital city of England and the United Kingdom.

place_556.name: Eisenerz
place_556.description: Eisenerz is an old mining and market town in the Austrian state of Styria.

place_555.name: Graz
place_555.description: Graz is Austria's second largest city.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_1246.name: Lima
place_1246.description: river in the Bagni di Lucca

place_932.name: Serchio
place_932.description: The third longest river in the Italian region of Tuscany at 126 kilometres.

place_615.name: Tiber River
place_615.description: The Tiber River is the third longest river in Italy. Rome is located on its banks.

place_952.name: Bagni di Lucca
place_952.description: A group of about 25 villages in northern Tuscany, less than 30 kilometres from Lucca, famous for its hot springs and thermal baths.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_1245.name: Lucignano
place_1245.description: municipality in the Province of Arezzo in the Italian region Tuscany

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).
